definition:
[*Bitwise AND*]{} is a bit-level operation on two binary values which
indicates which bits are set in both values. For each position $i$, if
and only if the bit $d_i$ in both values is 1, then $d_i$ of the result
is also 1, othewise, it’s 0. For example, given 50 and 163 in two
unsigned bytes, a bitwise AND returns 34.

  ----- --- --- --- --- --- --- --- ---
         0   0   1   1   0   0   1   0
    AND  1   0   1   0   0   0   1   1
      =  0   0   1   0   0   0   1   0
  ----- --- --- --- --- --- --- --- ---

In most high-level programming languages that offer bitwise AND, the
usual operator is a single ampersand (&), not to be confused with a
double ampersand (&&) which performs a Boolean AND, returning a True or
False value.

The Windows Calculator offers bitwise AND in scientific calculator mode,
while the Mac OS X Calculator offers it in programmer mode.
